title: iMessage History: Parental Absence & Emotional Neglect
description: Text messages showing pattern of emotional unavailability and dismissiveness from parent

message_history.message: Hey Dad! Hope you had a good week. How's work going?
Dad? Just checking in. Haven't heard from you in a while.
Got the promotion. Starts next month.
Congrats Dad!! üéâ
That's amazing Dad! Want to grab lunch to celebrate?
Swamped with transition meetings. Maybe later.
Happy November Dad! Want to do our usual coffee catch-up this month?
Hey Mom, has Dad mentioned if he wants to meet up? I texted him but haven't heard back.
You know how he is honey. He's busy with the new position.
I know, but we used to have coffee once a month. It's been 3 months.
He shows his love by working hard for this family. You should appreciate that.
Dad, I really would love to see you. Even just 30 minutes. I miss talking to you.
Busy season at work. We'll catch up soon.
Dad took me to lunch yesterday! Thanks for the career advice Dad ‚ù§Ô∏è
Hey, I didn't know you were seeing Dad. That's nice!
Yeah, he reached out because I had questions about a job transition.
That's great. I've been trying to get coffee with him for months üòÖ
You know Dad. He's more comfortable with 'purpose-driven' conversations.
Dad, can we please talk? I've been feeling really disconnected from you and it hurts. I just want to know how you're doing.
I'm here to ensure this family is prosperous, not to cater to you.
I'm not asking you to cater to me. I'm asking for basic connection. A phone call once in a while.
That's just not how I show love. I show love through providing. You should understand that by now.
You had time to have lunch with Emma but you don't have 30 minutes for me?
Emma needed career advice. That's different. That was productive.
And just talking to me isn't productive? I'm your kid too.
You're being too sensitive. Real men don't need constant check-ins.
I'm not asking for constant check-ins. I'm asking for SOME engagement. I live alone and it would mean something if you cared how I'm doing.
This conversation is over. You're being unreasonable.
Mom, what Dad just said to me really hurt. Can we talk about this?
Honey, that's just how your father is. You need to accept his love language.
His love language is absence? That doesn't make sense.
You're being ungrateful. He works so hard to provide for this family.
Rachel, do you ever feel like Dad is emotionally unavailable?
I mean yeah, but that's just how dads are. I don't take it personally.
But doesn't it bother you? He sees Emma but won't even text me back for months.
Emma needed something specific. Dad's better with tasks than feelings. Just accept him as he is.
So I'm supposed to just accept that my need for connection with my parent is too much?
I'm not saying it's too much. I'm saying he's not going to change. You're just hurting yourself by expecting something different.
Dad, what you said really hurt me. Can we please talk about it? I need you to understand why.
If you want to talk, call me. But I don't have much to say beyond what I already told you.

context_notes.pattern_established: Dad consistently unavailable ‚Üí Makes time for sisters when they 'need' something ‚Üí Frames protagonist's need for connection as weakness
context_notes.emotional_messaging: 'Real men don't need check-ins', 'I provide, that's love', 'You're too sensitive'
context_notes.family_normalization: Mom and sisters frame protagonist as expecting too much, normalize dad's absence
context_notes.protagonist_internalization: Beginning to question if their need for basic parental engagement is pathological
context_notes.triggering_statement: 'I'm here to ensure this family is prosperous, not to cater to you'
context_notes.current_state: Dad agreed to phone call but made it clear he stands by his position

roleplay_entry_point: Phone call with Dad where protagonist needs to express hurt without accepting dismissal, while managing self-doubt about whether their need is legitimate.
